content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Find a recipe for a low-carb breakfast on Allrecipes with at least 25 reviews. Show the Nutrition Facts and the total carbohydrate content per serving.  Please interact with https://www.allrecipes.com/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open search to find low‑carb breakfast recipe. Click Search button.
Action: Click 555
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Search textbox is focused, need to type query "low carb breakfast".
Action: Type 23; low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Search bar is not open; click Search button to reveal textbox.
Action: Click 555
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Use focused search textbox to look for low carb breakfast recipes.
Action: Type 23; low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to activate the search textbox before typing. I will click textbox element 23.
Action: Click 23
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The header search textbox element 22 might be a real input field; clicking it could enable typing.
Action: Click 22
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Try typing search query into header search textbox 22.
Action: Type 22; low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible search overlay contains a proper textbox element 23; I should type the query into it.
Action: Type 23; low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to activate search; clicking the “Click to search” button in the overlay might open a proper search field/page.
Action: Click 570
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Click the header search button (element 816) to trigger the proper search‑entry interface or search page where I can then type the query.
Action: Click 816
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Try entering the query “low carb breakfast” into the header search textbox element 22, which should accept text.
Action: Type 22; low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Activate the proper search textbox element 23 found in the overlay.
Action: Click 23
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Open the visible search overlay by clicking its “Click to search” button (element 570) so I can type the query.
Action: Click 570
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Now there is a real textbox element [23] labelled “Search”. I should type the search query into it.
Action: Type 23; low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to activate the actual input field for search; clicking the “Search” textbox element [23] should focus/convert it to a real input we can type in.
Action: Click 23
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Instead of struggling with the overlay search box, I can open the Meals category page (link 934) then navigate to Breakfast and apply low‑carb filter.
Action: Click 934
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Using Google will let me quickly locate a low‑carb breakfast recipe on Allrecipes that meets the review requirement.  
Action: Google
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need Google query. Use the search box (combobox 2) to look for low‑carb breakfast recipes on Allrecipes.
Action: Type 2; low carb breakfast recipe site:allrecipes.com
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Google shows a CAPTCHA “sorry” page; can’t proceed here. I should return to Allrecipes and use its own search/navigation instead.  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Try Google search again with a simpler query that may avoid the CAPTCHA, e.g., “Allrecipes low carb breakfast”.
Action: Type 2; Allrecipes low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Google search is blocked. I should leave Google and go back to the previous site (likely Allrecipes) where I can use on‑site navigation rather than Google.  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to return to the Allrecipes site we were on earlier to use its own search instead of Google.  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To locate a low‑carb breakfast recipe, I should use the site’s Search function.
Action: Click 510
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Search overlay textbox (element 6) is focused; entering the query here will run the site search.
Action: Type 6; low carb breakfast
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open the search overlay again so I can search for low‑carb breakfast recipes.
Action: Click 510
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need active search input; clicking “Click to search” button [525] should open a proper field to type my query.
Action: Click 525
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Open the Meals category listing so I can navigate to the Breakfast section and then filter for low‑carb recipes.
Action: Click 889
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: I need to open the search overlay to enter my query. The visible “Search” button (element 510) should expand the search field.
Action: Click 510

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
